p.s: In the following text StarrsStarr's state of mind is analyzed with the focus on narrative techniques.
Starr was afraid of the consequences of her speaking up about Khalil's death.
She also struggled a lot to process it.
In this passage she finally manages to overcome her fear and begins to speak up to the public.
The scene(s) is (are) told in the first person protagonist perspective which can be identifyedidentified by Starr talking about herself using I (ll. 5, 6, 15 etc.).
This perspective allows the readers to feel like they are also living this moment which makes them emphasize with the struggles of Starr.
It is also limiting the knowlegeknowledge of the readers so they are left in uncertanty about the events just as if they are part of the story themselfthemselves.

One narrative technique used is the reported thought (ll. 13-14) where Starr thinks about the absurdity of her attorney who is standing on a police car which contrasts with the task an attorney has: giving legal advide and support.
The flashback is used a lot in this passage.
Starr remembers the moments before Khalil was shot and the moment itself (ll. 5-7; 19-22).
The phrase that the crowd chants (A hairbrush is not a gun) (ll. 8, 16, 18, 20, 23) makes the reader jump back and forth in time which turns the one big flashback into small fragments.
In the lines 18-23 this is the most extreme because it starts with the chant mutter[ed] by Starr which is followed by a fragment.
This is repeated two times in total until Starr screams A hairbrush is not a gun! because she finnallyfinally overcomeovercomes her fear.
The back and forth in time splits and mixes her fear with her urge to tell the world what happened.
This is supported by Starr telling Ms. Ofrah that she wants to do something (l. 30).
A bit later in the book she speaks to the crowd about Khalil's death which further supports her breakthrough at this moment.
The flashback is presented in a scenic way which stresses her trauma that she got in the night when Khalil got shot.
The flashback is scenic because the description is very short and does not describe the entire situation and environment etc. but focuses only on a single detail each time.
In a nutshell this is a really important moment because Starr finally manages to speak up publicly without hesitation and fear.
The process of her overcoming that fear is made understandable for the reader by the narrative techniques.
